fileDesc.extent: Approx. 6KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 2 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

titleStmt.title: In Exeter-street, near Exeter-change in the Strand, next door to the Black-Moors-Head, liveth a gentlewoman.

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

keywords.term: Medicine -- Formulae, receipts, prescriptions -- England -- Early works to

2014-07 Kate AllenText and markup reviewed and edited

div.head: In Exeter-Street, near Exeter-Change in the Strand, next Door to the Black-Moors-Head, Liveth a Gentlewoman.
div.p: WHO by Gods blessing and diligent experience in Physick and Chirurgery for more then 20 years past, hath obtained many choice and powerful Remedies for most Diseases and Accidents in Humane Bodies, as may be seen in the following particulars.

1. An Electuary, which certainly cures a Consumption, or Coughs of the Lungs, although in the weakest condition, and many have been raised by it, that were nearly spent and confin'd to their Beds; it is indeed a Medicine of far greater Virtue then can be believed of it, and seldome fails of performing a Cure in three weeks time at furthest, price 5 s. the Pot; which is generally sufficient to perfect a Cure.

2. A Powder which perfectly cures the Jaundice in Young or Old, although the whole Skin be as Yellow as Saffron; it effectually removes the Cause in a few days time, and soon reduceth the Body to its wonted Colour and Complexion; it is likewise a most certain and speedy Cure for the Green-sickness. Melancholly, and Spleen, and helps Stoppages and Obstructions in Women, when nothing else can be found sufficient to do it; price 6 d. a Paper.

3. A Pill which powerfully easeth all pains in any part of the Body or Limbs; and helps the Cholick, griping of the Guts, Stitches in the Sides, pains in the Back, & Tooth-ach in an hours time; it presently stops Loosness and Vomiting, causeth rest, and infinitely adds strength to the whole body: Price 1 s. the Dose.

4. A Purging Electuary, which gives gentle Stooles, and keeps the body Laxative, without Griping or any discomposure, and is as good a Remedy as the World affords for stoppages, pains or sickness of the Stomach, want of Appetite, or a bad Distestion; It is likewise a present help in Colds, Coughs, Ptisick, Head-Ach, and Giddiness of the Head, Dropsies, Scurvies, and Cholick, and Cures all kind of Agues in a very short time, tho never so tedious or hard to Remedy; price 2 s. 6 d. the Pot.

5. A Powder for the Stone or Gravel, which immediately helps stoppage of Urine, and difficulty in making Water, it certainly dissolveth the Stone, and brings it away in a Sluny or Gravelly substance, without any pain; price 6 d. a Paper.

6. A Pill of great Efficacy in Surfeits and Feavers, discharging all crudities and other offensive matters by Stool, wonderfully
strengtheneth the Stomach, and infallibly Cures a stinking-breath, although of 20 Years standing; price 2 s. 6 d. the box containing 24 Pills.

7. An Oyntment which takes away all Pimples, Knobs, and Redness of the Face, be it never so great, and leaves it as smooth and well Coloured as ever in a few times using; it is a most certain Remedy and never fails to give satisfaction, price 3 s. the Pot.
8. A Powder and Oyntment, which certainly cures the Itch in a week or 10 days, although the whole body were over-run with it; and never so much broken out, price of the whole Remedy is 5 s.

She likewise helps the most grevious and out-ragious pains of the Head caused by a flowing or parting of the Skull, whereof many in a few days are brought to their ends, the cause being not rightly understood.

Also she presently gives Relief in the Pleurisie, although the Patient be nearly spent, and no hopes of help can be found; and cures Ruptures and Rickets in Children with much speed and certainty; Likewise Childrens sore Heads, though never so bad, destroying all the Vermin in one Nights time; she Infallibly Cures all Green Wounds, Burns or Scalds, (if not Mortal) Womens sore Breasts, though in a dangerous condition, and certainly helps Miscarriages, with other Accidents, belonging to Women in Child-bed; she likewise cures sore Eye and most Distempers of the sight, which for brevity sake are omitted: and hath a Powder which perfectly freeth the Body of all kind of Worms.

She hath likewise a most excellent Wash for the Face, which takes away all Freckles, Yellowness, or any deformity of the Skin, and makes it exceeding Fair and Youthful, price is from 1 s. 6d. to 10 s. the Vial.
Also a Spirit which whitens and fastens the Teeth to admiration, resstores wasted Gums, and perfectly freeth them from the Scurvy, soon making them of a fresh Reddy-colour. Price 2 s. 6 d the Vial.

She hath also a Paste for the Hands, exceeding all others this day in use, it powerfully cleanseth all foulness of the Skin, helps Ruffness, Chaping or Redness of the Hands, and makes them admirable soft, smooth, and white. Price 1 s 6d. the Pot.
☞ Such as have a desire for any thing herein Expressed, may have it carefully sent to them, either by a Messenger or Penny-Post, according to the Value set down; with Directions how to use them.
